Award.AbstractNarration: The Seminar on Stochastic Processes 2012 will take place on March 22-24, 2012 at the University of Kansas. These seminars have been held annually since 1981, and constitute the most important regular conference series for probabilists in the US. Many of the participants work on such topics as Markov processes, Brownian motion, superprocesses, stochastic analysis, or mathematical finance. The primary goal is to provide a platform for the dissemination of the most recent significant progress in research, and to encourage the interaction between junior and established researchers. The program includes five one hour lectures given by invited speakers and informal sessions emphasizing open problems of current interest.

Institution.Name: University of Kansas Center for Research Inc
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF KANSAS CENTER FOR RESEARCH, INC.

Performance_Institution.Name: University of Kansas Center for Research Inc

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
The main activity of this project has been to organize the Seminar on Stochastic Processes  2012, that was held at the University of Kansas from March 22 to March 24, 2012. The Seminar on Stochastic Processes is a series of annual conferences devoted to stochastic analysis, Markov processes and other topics in probability theory of current interest. It is one of the most important and popular national meetings focused on probability and stochastic processes. The Seminar provides young specialists and senior researchers an opportunity to discuss and work on recent advances on stochastic processes.

Following the tradition, the program of the Seminar consisted of five one hour invited lectures selected by the Scientific Committee and several informal sessions devoted to short presentations and open problems. The invited lectures were given by Jean-Francois Le Gall (University of Paris-Sud, Orsay, France), Bénédicte Haas (University of Paris-Dauphine, France), Martin Hairer (Warwick University, United Kingdom), Soumik Pal (University of Washington) and Giovanni Peccati (University of Luxembourg).

The Seminar  has been a  very successful event, with a total of 74 participants and 31 short presentations that covered a broad range of topics in probability and stochastic processes. Among the participants, 43 were PhD students and 5 were postdoctoral fellows.


Last Modified: 09/06/2013
Modified by: David Nualart
